{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Shapur II's Arab campaign |image=Nakhal Fort 1.jpg |caption=Picture of the [[Nakhal Fort]] and the [[Al Hajar Mountains|Hajar]] mountains]] |partof= |date= 325 |place=[[Persian Gulf]] littoral and [[Arabian Peninsula]] |territory= The Sassanian Empire establishes suzerainty over the [[Persian Gulf]] and numerous factions in Arabia |result= Decisive [[Sasanian]] victory{{cite web|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/shapur-ii |title=SHAPUR II |work=Encyclopaedia Iranica |author=Touraj Daryaee |publisher=Iranicaonline.org |date=July 20, 2009 |accessdate=September 6, 2013}} |combatant1=Arab tribes:
*[[Taghlib]] *[[Banu Bakr]] *[[Banu Abdul Qays]] |combatant2=[[Sasanian Empire]] |commander1= Unknown |commander2=[[Shapur II]] |strength1= Unknown |strength2= Unknown |casualties1=45,000 |casualties2=5,000 }} {{campaignbox Šāpūr the Great's Campaigns}} '''The Arab campaign of Shapur II''' took place in 325, against the Arab tribes of [[Arabia]]. [[Shapur II]] decisively defeated all the Arab tribes during his campaign, and became known as ''Dhū al-Aktāf'' ({{lang|ar|ذو الأكتاف}}, probably meaning “he who pierces shoulders”) to Arabs. ==History== ===Background=== During the childhood of Shapur II, [[Arabs|Arab]] nomads made several incursions into the Sasanian homeland of [[Fars Province|Pars]], where they raided [[Firuzabad, Fars|Gor]] and its surroundings.{{sfn|Daryaee|2009}} Furthermore, they also made incursions into [[Meshan]] and [[Maka (satrapy)|Mazun]]. ===The campaign=== At the age of 16, Shapur II led an expedition against the Arabs; primarily campaigning against the Ayad tribe in [[Asoristan]] and thereafter he crossed the [[Persian Gulf]], reaching al-Khatt, a region between present-day [[Bahrain]] and [[Qatar]]. He then attacked the [[Banu Tamim]] in [[Al Hajar Mountains|Hajar]] mountains. Shapur II reportedly killed a large number of the Arab population and destroyed their water supplies by stopping their wells with sand.{{sfn|Frye|1983|p=136}} After having dealt with the Arabs of eastern Arabia, he continued his expedition into western Arabia and [[Syria]], where he attacked several cities—he even went as far as [[Medina]].{{sfn|Potts|2012}} Because of his cruel way of dealing with the Arabs, he was called ''Dhū al-aktāf'' ("he who pierces shoulders") by them.{{sfn|Daryaee|2009}}{{sfn|Daryaee|2009|p=16}} Not only did Shapur II pacify the Arabs of the Persian Gulf, but he also pushed many Arab tribes further deep into the Arabian Peninsula. Furthermore, he also deported some Arab tribes by force; the [[Taghlib]] to Bahrain and al-Khatt; the [[Banu Abdul Qays|'Abd al-Qays]] and Banu Tamim to Hajar; the [[Banu Bakr]] to [[Kerman Province|Kirman]], and the Banu Hanzalah to a place near [[Ahvaz|Hormizd-Ardashir]].{{sfn|Daryaee|2009}} Shapur II, in order to prevent the Arabs to make more raids into his country, ordered the construction of a wall near [[al-Hira]], which became known as ''war-i tāzigān'' ("wall of the Arabs"). The Zoroastrian scripture [[Bundahishn]] also mentions the Arabian campaign of Shapur II, where it says the following: "During the rulership of Shapur (II), the son of Hormizd, the Arabs came; they took Khorig Rūdbār; for many years with contempt (they) rushed until Shapur came to rulership; he destroyed the Arabs and took the land and destroyed many Arab rulers and pulled out many number of shoulders".{{sfn|Daryaee|2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Pourshariati|first=Parvaneh|title=Decline and Fall of the Sasanian Empire: The Sasanian-Parthian Confederacy and the Arab Conquest of Iran|location=London and New York|publisher=I.B. Tauris|year=2008|isbn=978-1-84511-645-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I-xtAAAAMAAJ|ref=harv}} *{{cite encyclopedia | last = Shapur Shahbazi | first = A. | title = SASANIAN DYNASTY | url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/sasanian-dynasty | year = 2005 | encyclopedia = Encyclopaedia Iranica, Online Edition | accessdate = 30 March 2014|ref=harv}} [[Category:Battles involving the Sasanian Empire]] [[Category:325 in Asia]] [[Category:History of the Middle East]] [[Category:Banu Taghlib]] [[Category:Banu Bakr]] [[Category:Battles of pre-Islamic Arabia]] [[Category:History of the Persian Gulf]]
